awd_titl_txt: RI:  Small:  Collaborative Research:  Information-driven Autonomous Exploration in Uncertain Underwater Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops the theory and algorithms for autonomous navigation of mobile sensing platforms, such as unmanned ground, aerial, and underwater vehicles, so that the collected information is maximized while constraints on movement capabilities and energy expenditure are accommodated. This work facilitates the use of autonomous robots in environmental monitoring, search and rescue, surveillance and security, among other applications of societal importance. The algorithms are evaluated in field trials using unique gliding robotic fish.  The project provides training for both graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups. Through showcasing at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago and offering of an open-source robotic fish education kit, the project promotes the interest of K-12 students and the general public in science and engineering. The project further facilitates transfer of software and hardware for robotic sensing to the market.

The goal of this project is to bridge the gap between the theory and practice in information-driven mobile sensing and to develop a principled theoretic and algorithmic framework for autonomous exploration in uncertain, specifically underwater, environments. The approach exploits the concept of ergodic exploration, where the underlying optimization problem is solved using methods from nonlinear optimal control. The research consists of: 1) Establishing a rigorous theoretical framework for ergodic exploration for guaranteeing solution well-posedness and stability, and developing synthesis methods for real-time control; 2) exploring active probing of flow conditions via auxiliary measurement of tracer agents to mitigate environmental uncertainty; 3) investigating collaborative exploration schemes that strike balance among performance, complexity, and robustness; and 4) conducting field experiments to validate the framework using a group of gliding robotic fish to monitor harmful algal blooms and localize sources of chemical spills.

por.por_cntn:
Through an integrative investigation of theory, algorithms, and experiments, the project aimed to bridge the gap between the theory and practice in information-driven mobile sensing and develop a principled theoretic and algorithmic framework for realizing real-time autonomous exploration in uncertain environments, in particular, underwater environments. Among other tools, the project was centered around the concept of ergodic exploration, to take advantage of both exploitation and exploration during mobile sensing. Various underwater/surface robotic platforms were used to evaluate the theoretical findings and developed algorithms.

The project resulted in advances in the use of ergodic exploration for underwater sensing. For example, we developed an adaptive sampling strategy for mapping a scalar field in an underwater environment using a gliding robotic fish. To effectively deal with the challenging complexity of finding optimum three-dimensional trajectories that are feasible for the gliding robotic fish, we combined unicycle model-based 2D trajectory optimization with spiral-enabled water column sampling. Gaussian process (GP) regression was used to infer the field values at unsampled locations, and to update a (2D) map of expected information density (EID) in the environment using the mutual information metric, averaged over each water column. The outputs of GP regression were then fed back to the ergodic exploration engine for trajectory optimization. The advantage of the proposed approach was shown in simulation via comparison with a uniform sampling strategy.

The project contributed to the modeling and control of several types of robotic vehicles, such as gliding robotic fish, robotic fish, and robotic drifters. For example, for tail-actuated robotic fish, advanced control methods, including model-predictive control and backstepping control, were developed to effectively address the nonlinear dynamics. The efficacy of these methods was supported with extensive experimental results. Significant advances were also made on the modeling and control of robotic fish actuated by pectoral fins. In collaboration with Dr. Murphey's group at Northwestern University, this project contributed to a data-driven approach to the modeling and control of robotic systems using Koopman operators, where the control of robotic fish in the presence of significant environmental disturbances was used to illustrate the utility of the proposed approach.

The project led to the development and improvement of multiple robotic platforms, including gliding robotic fish, unmanned surface vehicles, and robotic drifters. Aside from directly supporting the theoretical and algorithmic components of this project, these platforms have become valuable testbeds for other projects related to mobile sensing in water, with applications in search and rescue, fish tracking, and water quality monitoring among others.

Collectively, the project contributed to 5 journal publications (3 published, 2 under review), 12 peer-reviewed conference papers, and 3 PhD dissertations. It provided training opportunities to 6 domestic PhD students (including one African American, one Hispanic female, and one with learning disabilities), 4 undergraduate students, and one K-12 teacher. The project contributed to various public and K-12 outreach activities, such as East Lansing Robotics Festival, High School Engineering Institute, Future Spartan Engineers Preview Day, and numerous lab tours and demos.
